<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Issue 239 - incremental number for filename
username_0: 
<issue_comment>username_1: - [ ] Nice Feature
- [ ] Adhering to code style
- [ ] Docs
- [ ] Tests
- [ ] References an issue that it solves

This might be the best PR I've ever seen on GitHub.
<issue_comment>username_2: Thanks for working on this @username_0 :)

I don't really see the point of making the delimiter configurable. I think we should just default to `(1)` like Chrome and many other apps do. We already have way too many option in Pageres. This seems non-essential.

Use https://github.com/username_2/unused-filename
<issue_comment>username_1: It sucks that Chrome, and other apps, append a nasty ` (x)` to filenames though. Not for any technical reason that I can think of, but just because it looks stupid/nasty (to me, and I'm sure others).

It's like that nasty ` copy` to ` copy 2` thing OSX does.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/224636/21052086/3c078e8c-bdf1-11e6-8e6a-aa031e33e316.png)

I don't think there is a standard between operating systems/apps for the naming convention of duplicated files, so I'm not sure why trying to adhere to one here makes sense.

It seems fine to use https://github.com/username_2/unused-filename to do this, but unused-filename doesn't offer customizing. Would you consider adding the ability to customize to unused-filename?
<issue_comment>username_2: "Stupid/nasty" is not a constructive argument. The parens make it clearer that the number is not part of the filename.
<issue_comment>username_0: Thanks @username_1 :)

Hello @username_2, I made the delimiter configurable because there were different opinions about the convention to use in the issue's discussion. 

Nevertheless, I am available to define a default behavior if it is the best option. I can also change the 'increment' option name to another name that is clearer for the user. 

I didn't know the [unused-filename](https://github.com/username_2/unused-filename) project. I will check it when possible.
<issue_comment>username_1: "XYZ isn't constructive" is literally the least-constructive/most-overused phrase in FOSS. Please inspect the meaning of comments before accusing them of being nonconstructive.

"it looks stupid/nasty" was a light-hearted way of saying some people don't like that "convention" (aka: non-existent OS standard) and would just like the ability to customize it to their tastes.

Again, no one cares if you make parens (or whatever) the default (in fact, it's probably a good idea to for unused-filename to [default to OS-specific conventions](https://github.com/username_2/unused-filename/issues/3)), we'd just like to be empowered to customize more things and less purism -- unless there's a good reason for the purism which I'm happy to hear about.

I'll bow out of this PR now since I'm afraid further discussion will detract from @username_0 good work.
<issue_comment>username_2: Any suggestion? Maybe `overwrite` and with `true` by default.
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 is this new version ok?

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Underscores (_) in documentation not treated as word break in search
username_0: Example:

If you go to the [Phoenix PubSub docs](https://hexdocs.pm/phoenix_pubsub/Phoenix.PubSub.html) and search for "pool" you get exactly one result, which is in the Phoenix.Tracker behaviour, and that's probably not what you were looking for.

However, search for `pool_size` and you add the Phoenix.PubSub.child_spec function to the list, and that's _probably_ what you were looking for.

Expected (Requested?) Behavior:

Seems like when searching, underscores in the source material should be treated as word breaks so that you can match on "partial underscores", useful for searching for configuration elements (which are often snake-cased, like this one).  So a search for "pool" should bring up matches on `pool_size` as well as `pools` and `use_pool?` (I made up the last one as an example).

Preferably, if the input search term has an underscore, the underscore should match underscores (so searching for "pool_size" only matches `pool_size` and/or `max_pool_size`, but not `pool size`
<issue_comment>username_1: Please open this issue on: https://github.com/elixir-lang/ex_doc<issue_closed>
